reviewText:
Kane and Lynch 2: Dog Days is the worst video game I have ever played.

The story begins with Kane and Lynch in Shanghai trying to scrape together a gun running deal.  Before the deal goes down, Lynch drags Kane to go settle a grudge match with some guy for some reason.  The duo accidentally kill a girl who happens to be the daughter of some government bureaucrat with enough money, power, and influence to not only control his own gang, but the police and even the Chinese military.  His goons pursue Kane and Lynch.  Kane and Lynch get caught and tortured.  What follows is the most gruesome, unncessary, and tasteless sequence in an already awful game, in which we see our lovely protagonists running around naked and covered and blood.  Then they get captured again, get taken to the villain's building, and decide to kill him while they're there, because why not?  After killing him, they escape, and the player is left wondering what the point was.

Because having a shallow, pointless, and disgusting plot wasn't enough, the game also features a shallow, pointless, and disgusting graphical gimmick.  The entire game is designed to look like it's being filmed on a handheld camera.  This makes no sense in-universe since nobody with a camera is actually following the duo around.  The result is shaky cam that would disgust Paul Greengrass, horrible looking lens flares, and a generally disgusting visual aesthetic.  The effect is amplified when running, and will make you want to puke as the visuals go out of focus and shake wildly.  Just charming!

The gameplay is built around simple, co-operative third person shooting.  It's about as standard and bland as it can get.  Headshots instant-kill enemies that would otherwise be massive bullet sponges.  You hide behind cover (which feels miserable).  There are the mandatory stealth" sequences that don't actually work.  A turret level.  Shooting down helicopters.  Pretty much all of it is standard to the point of being boring

reviewText:
I don't usually recommend games that are physically painful to play, but Kane & Lynch 2: Dog Days has managed to defy the odds and gain my love.

I'd like to preface this review by saying that I have not played the first game, Dead Men, in the series, but I am fully up to date with the story and many of the gameplay elements. The first one never drew in my attention because of certain mechanics it used, but this one did.

Kane & Lynch 2: Dog Days is the second instalment in a third person cover based action shooter game series focused around the stories of two guys. Kane, and Lynch. Kane, a man with a questionable past and morals (who was the main playable character in the first game) has come to Shanghai to visit his... partner, Lynch, a literal psychotic with who he has worked with before, in order to do some business with him. I won't help into too many details, but as expected, things go bad really quickly, and you're thrust into a non stop action thrill ride that will either make you violently ill, or wanting more.

What do I mean by this? Well, if you've played the first game, you'll know that it was a fairly normal feeling third person shooter, in which you played as Kane and focused on his story. Now, the focus is put on Lynch, the psychotic. And boy, the game sure does feel like it was made with you actually controlling a psychotic. If Dead Men was a Kane focused normal third person shooter, Dog Days is a Lynch focused psychotic trip.

The way this is accomplished is mainly by the visuals and camera, which I feel is one of the biggest draws in the game. The visuals in Dog Days behave as though the entire game was being filmed by someone with a camera. There are visual artefacts, intense glare, and blur/pixelation effects used throughout the game. When you get shot, you might see your screen go fuzzy in some areas. If you see a bright light, you might get intense glare. If you shoot a civilian in the face, you might get a pixelated area where their face should be. These are all really neat features and really help to make the game feel like a video. While these have a relatively minor impact on gameplay, there is one more effect that is always in use that may make or break the game for you. The screen shake.

The screen in this game is ALWAYS shaking. And I do mean ALWAYS. Even when you're crounching behind an obstacle, the screen is still shaking slightly. Sprinting make the camera shake like you'd expect someone sprinting with a video camera would. You get shot? Shaking. You need to run? Shaking. Getting into cover? Do you even need an answer? And considering this game really is non stop action with hardly even a minute of relaxation every now and then, the screen is going to be shaking more than wet dog that's had 50 cups of cold coffee in the snow. This shaking, along with the other effects, can make the game more difficult to play, and can make it difficult to see enemies sometimes, it is also the cause of many headaches from many people, and it's clear to see why. And yet, I absolutely adore this feature. Once again, it really helps with giving the game a gritty feel, and a sense of speed and urgency. Everything is always moving so fast, and Lynch, being a psychotic, obviously has a harder time dealing with it than most people. He's in constant pain, and to a degree, you feel this as well.

Speaking of fast, by god is this game fast paced There's no collectables or anything to slow you down, and the game in constantly RUN AND SHOOT COVER AND SHOOT RUN AND SHOOT COVER AND SHOOT REPEAT FORVER! The game can be pretty difficult as it doesn't take much for you to get killed, but you also regenerate life fairly quickly and this works really well. Since you play as Lynch for the majority of the game, you always have the computer (or other player) controlling Kane, who is with you for almost the entire game. You can't give him any commands or whatever and he just deals with things himself, and he can't die, so there's no reason to pay mind to him. But the banter between the characters in game is really enjoyable and he doesn't have any negative effect on the game at all. The game is build around having these 2 together and it does so well. If you hate having an extra character constantly tag alone, like Ashley is RE4, Shiva in RE5, or Alyx in HL2, I assure you, the game works really with both of these characters and you are still in complete control the entire time. No waiting for the other character, no inventory management, no revival, or anything like that exists. At least not in single player. In multiplayer, a revival mechanic does exist, but not the other stuff.

However while the game is really fast paced, naturally, the game is also over really fast. It takes only 4 hours to beat the main campaign, and I'm counting deaths. If you managed to beat this game without dying (extremely difficult even on normal difficulty and probably on easy, I'd say I died about 100 times on my first playthrough, and don't worry, there's VERY frequent checkpoints) then you're looking at maybe 3  or 2 and a half hours of straight gameplay. While this is a con, the game is VERY jam packed and never has a dull moment to lengthen it out. It also have several extra missions that you can play alone or in multiplayer which add a few hours. I also feel the game is very replayable, as there are no skills trees or anything to worry about. This is a game that starts fast and keep going.

The story, while nothing particularly noteworthy, does at least draw you into the feelings and thought of the 2 main characters, who are still totally jerks, but ones that you can't help but feel sorry for.

Music that shows up now and then isn't very noticeable and very forgettable, but isn't bad, and sound effects are fine for the most part. There are some glitches in the game, like the screen going grey and not showing the game, but these are rare and usually fixed just by restarting the game. The weapons feel pretty good to me to be honest, but some seem to not like the sound of them. True, they don't feel overly strong, but since you're shooting 90% of the time anyway, I feel that they feel strong enough. Some of the guns also feel as though they have little to no accuracy to them (except the shotguns, which have a pretty good range for most videogame shotguns) but these weapons are quickly replaced by much better guns with better accuracy. In general, the gunplay feels quite good, covering works fine (most of the time), and it's a joy to play.

Sometimes, it also feels like the game hates you, as some parts are incredibly difficult, even at the start, and the ending really seems to come out of nowhere and leaves you asking was that it... seriously?"

reviewText:
While the original Kane and Lynch may be remembered for its review controversy, for me, it was a title that really tried to do something fresh and unique in a lot of ways. Kane and Lynch: Dead Men had main characters that were difficult to like, but by the end of the dark and compelling story to save Kane’s family, players felt a bit of Stockholm Syndrome for the duo. The co-op, while offline only, offered a unique perspective for both players, something we rarely see in the age of co-op clone characters. The sequel has arrived and our anti-heroes are back again, this time across the world in Shanghai with Lynch’s story as the focus. But can Kane and Lynch 2: Dog Days recapture the same fresh feeling of the first game?

The story of Dog Days has Kane meeting up with his old pal Lynch who promises a job with plenty of riches. Upon Kane’s arrival a simple task for the two turns sour and inadvertently starts a gang war. Soon you realize that your deal is going south as your contact is attacked in an intense highway assault and you make a desperate attempt to escape with all your lives. It wasn’t long after this I lost what was going on, the overall purpose of what the duo was doing.

Despite some great voice acting and plenty of memorable lines - I had completely forgot the purpose of what I was doing midway through the title. “Why am I shooting these army guys again?” I asked my co-op partner. It had something to do with a big Chinese mob boss and not dieing, but beyond that everything is a bit of chaos. Perhaps this is what IO Interactive was going for, as the main character this time is Lynch, who’s not exactly mentally stable. There’s plenty of times Lynch voices over to himself, trying to use psychological tricks to calm his nerves - no doubt from some sort of therapy sessions.

The graphical style and display are going to be the most memorable and controversial piece to this game, the shaky YouTube style camera is either going to be a complete turn off or something people really like. At moments the grainy and over saturated look of the game world makes it look eerily realistic. The neon glow of lights bouncing off reflective surfaces, the distant city line of Shanghai, and the dark alleys all can trick your eye in an almost photo realistic moment. Other times poor textures in certain areas, stiff character animation and improper lip syncing totally break the immersion.

Shortly into my first mission I almost felt nauseous from the camera movement - but it passed. The shaky camera is only really bad while running and once you get used to it, it provides some useful info on enemy position and adds to the immersive effect. Thankfully if you can’t get over it you can disable it, though it’s still there to some degree.

IO Interactive really wanted to have the feeling of intense and gritty shoot outs. They wanted your palms sweaty and your grip tightening on your controller through every twist and turn. To some degree, this holds true. There were times the firefights were memorable, with exploding objects and cover flying everywhere as bullets rained down on Kane and Lynch. The atmosphere is further enhanced by Asian inspired pop music blasting from in game radios and intercoms, giving it an almost John Woo movie feel in certain situations.

Sadly the intensity is broken once you realize the firefights break down into duck, pop up wait for guy to peak his head out of cover, and shoot mechanic. This style of combat is rinse and repeat for most of the game with save for a few battles. Which is sad, because some of the key moments like a helicopter attack on and in an office building and a mission where you need to cover Lynch’s girlfriend in an apartment building across the street are really fun. The level after Kane and Lynch are tortured is one that will be forever burned into my retinas. I just wish there was more of these moments.

Kane and Lynch 2 does make a huge improvement in terms of co-op options over it’s predecessor. Full online play and local play is supported and there’s options for matchmaking too. And while the single player is fun, like all good co-op games, playing this with a friend is much more satisfying. You can really tell that K&L 2 was designed from the ground up for co-op play; level layouts are well crafted into separate paths for cover and flanking maneuvers and there’s a nice balance of weapons to choose from for both close and long range giving players defined roles. One thing that sadly appears to be missing is some of the crazier elements of Lynch from the first game - instance where the players actually see different things. As far as we could tell they weren’t as prominent as the cops/civilians bank scene from the first game.

Co-Op makes the game a bit easier as well. While in the single player game if you get shot you’ll get knocked down and have a chance to get up, a second subsequent knock down will kill you. In co-op this second knockdown is actually revivable by your co-op partner. This can help in some of the trickier situations when the game is throwing what seems like hundreds of guys your way only to be killed by the last group and having to do it all over again. While the checkpoint system seems ok, it never seems to be quite enough, and starting a co-op game will lose any single player checkpoint progress - so you’ll need to restart back at a chapter beginning.

It’s these little nagging issues that constantly remind you that perhaps Kane and Lynch 2 wasn’t quite ready. I hit numerous technical bugs as well - mostly while playing as a guest co-op player over Xbox Live. Cut scenes were missing characters, character animations got stuck, audio cut out on me completely, and the game even crashed at one point. Strangely while playing solo or as the host these seemed almost non existent.

If you don’t want to play Fragile Alliance online there’s a new Arcade mode where you can use all AI guys and try to get the highest score possible. This mode is surprisingly addictive, though, it does get a bit long in the tooth by the 9th or 10th round. The game will up the difficulty with every round and you can keep going until you run out of your 3 lives.

So does Kane and Lynch 2 deliver that fresh feeling of the first game? Sadly I don’t think it does. While IO did a great job of fixing the cover and shooting mechanic, adding online co-op, and deepening the addictive multiplayer modes - it seems the rest of the game suffered as a result. With two characters as memorable and unique as Kane and Lynch, I was sad to see the story - which took only 5 hours to complete - a bit lacking. Don’t get me wrong, Kane and Lynch 2: Dog Days isn’t a bad game, it’s just not a great one.

The Co-Op Experience: Team up online or offline through the story in co-op with a friend. Play as Kane or Lynch and work together with a revival mechanic. Online play allows 8 players to rob a bank together in a Fragile Alliance that can turn co-op into competitive.

Co-Op Score: 3.5 out of 5
General Score: 3 out of 5

reviewText:
KANE & LYNCH: DOG DAYS
A flawed follow up to Kane & Lynch: Dead Men that covers much the same ground.

Rating 4/10

Great art style, setting and characters in a story that doesn't go anywhere. Its greatest strength is the style; similar to lo-fi handheld shaky cam. The setting of Shanghai is also well realised, showing the seedy underbelly with bustling streets and markets however in later levels it reverts to overused locations such as warehouses and docks.

It also suffers the same problems as Kane and Lynch: Dead Men, great characters but stale and awkward gameplay. Simple mechanics such as getting into cover can be tricky and the aiming is clumsy at times. There also aren't any real variants on the gameplay, often narrow alleyways where it's a repetitive game of whack a mole, popping in and out of cover until it's safe to proceed.

The recent Spec Ops had an interesting story to make up for it's lack of gameplay, Kane and Lynch Dog Days has two great disaster-prone characters but not a great story.

It's also so short the first time I completed it I thought it was the end of Act 1 only to realise it was the end of the game, and incredibly short single player campaign that ends suddenly.  Multiplayer isn't much better as it died a month or so after release and now it's impossible to find other players.

There are far better 3rd person shooters out there now such as Kane and Lynch: Dead Men, Max Payne 3 and Spec Ops which all do it better. Worth picking up for the art style alone but don't expect much from the game.

reviewText:
The first game finished so badly (one of the ending anyways) that it had to continue with Kane & Lynch 2. Thats a good thing, right ? Nope. Not here.  The story uses the same overused theme thats been done in movies and games since the beginning of games...revenge. Its predictable from start to finish which is kind of boring if you think about it. Theres no more character dept and Kane stops Lynch from learning more from each other right from the start, Personally I think its the biggest mistake that the devs made.

For the gameplay, I have to be honest what impressed me the most are 2 things. First is the enemy AI...It's brutal. If you take cover and don't look around you, the enemy will come up to you and ♥♥♥♥ you up. That is impressive since most AI will just stay behind cover and shoot you endlessly without anything more to do.

Second is the cover system. Far from perfect but at least this time I press C to activate it so in a very wierd way...its works. Since Kane & Lynch : Dead Men, the cover didn't work almost all the time.

The game forces you to change weapons since enemies don't use all the same weapon so its possible you'll run out of ammo for a specific weapon so you'll have to change. I personally don't mind that because it forces you to change strategy to kill your enemies (don't snipe with a shotgun) and you have to think about ammo conservation as well.

Level design is the most absurb thing besides the story of course. What you see is only Shanghai city...its the same view you get from room to room, to buildings to ... well everything looks the same. So level design is just really bad, boring not appealing at all.

Story doesn't make any sense to me, why the hell are they staying in Shanghai ? Everyone in the city goes after them and the only thing they have in mind is...complete the transaction...stay here. WTF ??? It's just an excuse to use the same textures over and over....and I completed the game in 4 hours...shorter than the first one.

Sorry but this is not recommended. If at least they would of done a great job with the level design I would of recommended this. If you add everything with the bad levels, the game becomes unacceptable.
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText: You might wanna ask why don't I recommend this game based on four hours playtime. Well guess what, that's how long it took me to beat it. I finished it in one evening in co-op with my friend. And that's the only reason I really enjoyed those four hours. Because I played the story in multiplayer. Otherwise everything is wrong. The enemy is dumb as hell, the story sucks, the gameplay is somehow weird - but that might be me, and before you can get into the story" or to know the characters it's over with the most wtf are you kidding me ending ever to be seen. I thought it's a bug when the credits came up. If I bought this game for full price at the time it was released I am pretty sure I would have sent some unpleasant package to the developers right away. Play this if you wanna do some shooter with your friend in co-op and you're not interested in non-story multiplayer like CS or CoD or such are. Otherwise there's no reason to even touch this."

reviewText:
I don't know quite what to say about this game. It has contempt, utter contempt, for videogames and for the player, and it's ugly -- very, very ugly. They've done something very strange here; it's a game about bad people doing bad things and destroying themselves because of it.

The protagonists are not likeable, and the people they kill are only trying to kill them because Kane and Lynch tried to kill them first. It's very stylized, but the style is terrible -- the whole game, from beginning to end, looks like a badly framed video shot handheld on a terrible camcorder.


People criticize it for being too short, which was valid when it was Sixty US Dollars, but is no longer the case. If you want to play a cover shooter for thirty hours, you're probably not going to want to play a game which seems to deliberately destroy everything that justifies those games.



This is a game about the death of the American Dream. Play it.

reviewText: The camera is insanely shaky. Until I found the setting to disable it, I literally couldn't tell what was going on in the game. Shooting mechanics are also pretty terrible with every weapon having ~3% accuracy. I'd be okay if weapons had imperfect accuracy like a Gears of War game, but the sheer amount of enemies who are almost always in near perfect cover makes for tedious fights that force you to charge ahead only because your ammo capacity is too low for a firefight.

reviewText:
I'm recommending this on the premise that I got this from a sale at $2.50

At this price, it's worth it to me. Players can skip the DLC because most of it pertains to the multiplayer which many players have moved on from this point in time.

Treat this game as a B rated movie with some realistic sentiments from those that wheel and deal in illegal contraband. It isn't anything really special when it comes to acting and the set pieces.

As for the gameplay, it's a generic third person shooter.  For a game in recent memory, Spec Ops follows this same flow as well: 2-3 weapons, regenerating health and pop out of cover-drop some guys.  Rinse and repeat.

Also for those that are curious about play time, it's about 3 hours long with gameplay and watching all of the cutscenes.

reviewText:
If ever there were a time to recommend Kane & Lynch 2, now would be that time.

With the sudden glut of shooters focused on characters going mad, the darkness of the average video-game player-character, and what I see as the start of unique artistic approaches to games (see: Routine, Tangiers, etc), it should be clear that this game was well before its time.

It was critically derided, despite being Spec Ops: The Line's nasty older brother. The censored headshots turn a stomach far faster than the gory over the top madness of any other game that comes to mind. The visual style is bright, eyepopping, unique, will never be seen again due to gamers not being ready for the game when it was released.

This game is worth a playthrough if you want to taste blood, smell sweat, hate yourself. That is in no way a point against it as a game -- it is uniquely visceral, and we will have a hard time seeing another game willing to go so far until the critical backlash from it is forgotten.

reviewText:
Pros -  Some degree of realism.  Shots to the head or upper torso kill you instanty (in  Extreme  difficulty atleast). Shots to other body parts hurt you or knock you down.
-  Nice setting.  You get a glimpse of the dangerous life in the dark alleys of Shanghai.

Cons -  The camera is horrible.  I don't understand what the developers were going for. The shaky portable-like camera during sprints and cutscenes was a bad idea. It didn't make the game any better, it makes your life more difficult. On the bright side, you can turn on Steady Camera.

-  The aim system is bad...  I couldn't find a better way to put this. I know aiming a gun in real life isn't easy but the way it behaves in this game makes  Extreme  difficulty unnecessarily stupid. Enemies have incredible aim and range (they are police officers, SWAT agents and Shanghai gangsters after all), they can headshot you from a ridiculous distance or atleast kill you with a couple of shots. In my opinion, the least the game could do is let you aim your guns properly from the same range (or any range above 10 feet (~3 meters)) to stand a chance.

-  Checkpoints are too spaced.  Yes, this is one of  those  games. You spend half an hour trying to get through a tough spot or a difficult situation where you're always outnumbered and outgunned, only to be killed by that last single ************. What happens? You start way back there, one or maybe two areas before that one. Again, really frustrating in  Extreme  difficulty.

-  Graphics.  Not as relevant as the former cons but still. They aren't total garbage but they're not good either. Some edges and textures are poor and the shaky camera just makes it worse (or better if it can distract you from them).

In conclusion, I wouldn't recommend this to most people. If you like the chinese setting and/or old school clunky gameplay go ahead and try it. Or if you're that guy that wants to try every shooter out there, try it aswell. But don't say I didn't warn you :P

Oh and don't judge me on only 3 hours game time. I had played this before without Steam and I thought I'd play it one more time. Not one of my best decisions... I stand by what I've said in this review.

reviewText:
2/5. BAD GAME !

OVERALL Have you forced yourself of finishing a game just to see if you get to enjoy it down the road? Well, that's what this game was for me, it's a really unrefined shooter and would never pay $10 for it, I got it in a bundle but wouldn't pay more than $3 for it, and even then I would rather expend the $3 on an indie game who will be over 5h of fun.

REPLAYABILITY Once you finish this dull adventure and try to squeeze a little more of fun from it you may replay a couple of levels to get some achievements, I did so in about 35min just to convince myself to never ever touch this tittle again.

GAMEPLAY The shooting is horrible unless you are using a shotgun at close range, assault rifles or pistols at mid or sniper at long, other than that forget altogether the SMGs unless you want to save some bullets and prepare to be frustrated with the low accuracy of the guns when they are in your hands and the ultra high precision they get on AI hands, seriously the reticle of the AI is perfect and you get one the size of a watermelon.

AESTHETIC The visuals of your surroundings might be the best part of the game, and that's not something to brag too much about, however the character models are bland and don't look very good, shooting cars and some elements in the environment might be what gives your heart content at the end of the day, after gunning down your enemies of course.

STORY If you look at the big picture the story isn't THAT bad, but while playing it it feels very uninspired, there are parts that are really stupid and to make it worse you have to deal with some horrible animations and rather dull voice acting (the phone calls between chapters are the best voice acting you will get, I guess not looking at the stiff animations helped). In my opinion the story twists were pretty dumb, *SPOILER ALERT*  when you get caught and thrown into the garbage after been cut off by a butcher you were supposed to be dead, but no, you get back into the building and manage to kill the bad dudes with your bare hands...  that's the dumbest moment in my opinion.

MUSIC The ambient sounds and gun shooting aren't bad, but in the end the score is pretty forgettable, you know, if there was any...

reviewText:
A sequel to a 2006's generic third person cover based shooter - Kane & Lynch: Dead Men. You'd have think, that after a failure that was the first instalment of Kane & Lynch, IO Interactive would carefully analyse all the feedback and adjust to it. Sadly this isn't a case. While K&L2 no longer uses GFWL and allows to play cooperatively over the internet (finally?), it still has all the flaws of the first game. Hell - it even has few more.

Firstly, Lynch's episodes of violent psychosis? No longer present in the game! It's kind of depressing that IO basically killed the most interesting (although, certainly - not positive) aspect of Lynch.
What is also a step back, comparing to original is the music. Jesper Kyd - the composer behind music to Assassin's Creed, Hitman series and many others... no longer present in here. And sadly - a music of a new composer - Mona Mur doesn't really work. It isn't bad - it's just so easily forgettable.

Forgettable is also a word, that describes storyline of Kane & Lynch 2. After the first level, everything is based around the same idea - you trying to escape from Shanghai. It's OMG
date: we have to get out of Shanghai... Lynch
recommended: let's get your girlfriend and then we go" (*level later*) "Plan failed... it's all your fault
hoursPlayed: Kane... she's dead... you've destroyed my life (blahblahblah) let's get out of Shanghai". How does it end? Kane and Lynch get to the plane and leave Shanghai.\n\nWhole storyline takes around 3-5hrs to complete
voteText: which is just a terrible length for a game
helpfulPercent: where singleplayer is focal point of the game. There is a multiplayer and you can play the game in COOP. Problem is - I was never able to find anyone playing anything except COOP. And while playing a game in COOP certainly helps - it doesn't even add much replayablity (at least nowhere near as much as COOP in most of shooters).\nWhat kills the game however is its gameplay mechanics and terrible visuals. I get the difference between aesthetics and graphics and I do understand importance of artistic vision. And to some extend I do admire it's interesting visual style. Problem is - all of the post-processing effects get in the way of gameplay. With all the intense lens-flare effects
votesHelpful: noise
votesTotal: color correction etc. not only spotting enemies becomes difficult. It's hard to aim and shoot. And when you disable them - you are left with nothing but highly outdated graphics
votesFunny: that look like something from 2003 (although - aesthetically
commentsCount: Unreal Tournament 2003 still looked better than K&L2)\nShooting in K&L2 lacks impact and isn't satisfying. Combine that with a glitchy cover mechanics and you have 2 main reasons why K&L2 fails to be an enjoyable shooter. What makes the cover mechanics even worse is something what should have worked in game's favour - destructible environment. Destructible environment sounds cool

reviewText:
Repellant and pointless.  Kane and Lynch 2 is the worst kind of bad game, one made by a developer with the talent and resources to have done something better.  What goes wrong here-and it's just about everything- feels deliberate, not the result of inexperience or a lack of money.

The protagonists are utterly unlikeable and barely developed except to constantly reinforce their odious nature. The story goes nowhere, the gameplay is nothing but repetitive shooting behind cover, and the shakycam/lensflare effects are obnoxious.

Mercifully, the experience ends with a soggy whimper after a brief 4 hours.

Everyone's got one game that they consider the worst they've ever played, and this is mine.  Avoid at all costs.

reviewText:
I'd heard hype for this game, but honestly it fell down in expectations for me. Take this with a grain of salt as I haven't played the full game. Can't bring myself to play it anymore.

PROS: Little to no lag in co-op, tight control scheme

THINGS I HAVEN'T DONE (before you complain about my cons section): Whole story, multiplayer, the first game

CONS: repetitive gameplay, little variety in weapons, strange camera which wobbles, very arcade-styled, not much depth.

All you do is run from cover to cover shooting at people for no other reason than to shoot from what I've seen. Frankly, I could have saved the $10 I spent on this for a plethora of better games.

reviewText:
Being an IO game I really wanted to like it, but I just don't. In fact, I have a hard time even comming up with something positive to say. Sure, the weird hand-held camera view is somewhat stylish, but it quickly just gets annoying. Also, who's filming and why? And why is gore and nudity censured?

The guns are weak, and doesn't really feel like they do any damage. The story, well, I never really got it - you hunt someone in the beginning, and your girlfriend gets *snip*, and you hunt the people behind? From all previews I thought it would be about a robbery, but that's only the multiplayer part (or arcade mode).

I've played 4.4 hours so far, and that's 3.5 hours of completing the whole campaign(!), and 0.9 hours playing arcade mode. I'll try to complete the co-op campaign, and then I'll just try to forget this game...

reviewText:
(As i'm writing this, i'm expecting a lot of hate for this review.. In case anyone happens to read this in the first place.)

Kane And Lynch 2 is a good.. Well at the very least a competent third person shooter. It's almost literally like Payday The Heist/Payday 2 except that it doesn't have nearly as much depth or content as those two games mentioned before. That being said, I feel like this is still a better game than THOSE TWO GAMES MENTIONED BEFORE. Allow me to tell you why:

People always complain and whine about the length of the Story in this one, yeah you can finish it in 2 or 3 hours, yeah it's very linear, yeah it's very repititive.. But at least this game has a f*cking story mode to begin with. Which Payday doesn't.. The reason why i'm comparing K&L2 to the PAYDAY series because they're so similar to each other gameplaywise.

The Characters, Kane & Lynch (who woulda guessed?) are also pretty cool and brutal characters.. Very interesting characters indeed since they're sort of evil people. The game has character development, does the PAYDAY series do any of these? Nah.

Also, the multiplayer mode is pretty decent if i do say so myself if it wasn't dead.
It's 9,99 Euros guys.

PAYDAY 2 is 29,99 Euros.

Despite the short story mode it's a good game. And the multiplayer being dead really isn't even that big of a deal considering you can play the Multiplayer with AI. And the friendly AI in this game manages just fine, compared to PAYDAY. Since in the PAYDAY series you have objectives that you must complete in order to progress through the match or whatever, in K&L2 you get the loot and get the f*ck out. The AI is competent enough in K&L2, in PAYDAY, it isn't.

I hope my gibbering nonsense has made some sense and given you some new perspective about this game.

TL;DR IT'S PAYDAY 2 WITH LESS CONTENT, DEPTH AND THIRD PERSON VIEW.

Note: When i talk about depth i mean the multiplayer, PAYDAY 2 has a LOT more of guns and other cool stuff to waste your money at.

reviewText:
This game is utter garbage not worth one dollar, Dog days is a doggy bag of flaming $h!%.  See the M rating, it doesnt matter because the entire game is censored, if you shoot anyone you get this mosaic box that appears.  There is NO way to disable this mosaic box making the game just feel like... a game, so theres no immersion.  Whats annoying is the graphics are great, someone took the time to make a great looking game, but everytime you shoot someone invisible parents step in blocking us from seeing the terrible violence.  Odd the game lets you shoot people but not see their shot bodies, this is something anomalous in gaming, unique to this game.  Look at the screenshots, notice NONE of them are censored.  Marketing wasnt stupid they only used screenshots that didnt include the censored in game footage because they knew noone would buy this crap.  Its time we kick out these game devs and put the marketing team in there making games, because these guys dont have a clue about game design.

Watch ANY gameplay footage, K&L2 looks like its made by an 8 year old with a video editor, it uses EVERY filter making it almost impossible to see the game at times, from lens flare, to blood over your screen, static boxes, just open up a video editor see all those effects?  Their ALL in K&L2 with most being impossible to disable like that stupid censorship box.

Get Kane and Lynch 1 since Kane and Lynch 2 sucks.

Rating:  0/10  Value:  $-9,999,999.00 (<---they should be paying us to play this kind of trash)

reviewText:
This is a very short game, but that doesn't necessarily make it bad. Although you can finish the singleplayer in a day, the characters and action make it something everyone should try. I've never seen a game with such a unique set of characters that make you love them and hate them at the same time. The faux video camera style of the game is really something to be seen.

The multiplayer is also fun for a couple of rounds, but it really isn't anything to keep you playing for days.

Is it worth $20? No.
Is it worth $5? Yes.

reviewText:
I think I got this game on sale in 2010 for about 5 bucks or so. Even at that price, I really can't recommend it.

When I first tried playing the game, I got DESTROYED by run of the mill enemies that could seemingly shoot through my cover and flank me with the greatest of ease. I got frustrated and shelved the game for 5 years. I'm not sure what bug crawled up my backside, but I decdied to install the game and grind away until  I saw the game through completion.

I really enjoy the atmosphere in this game, and I am probably one of the few who actually enjoy the 'shaky cam' aspect/angles they were going for. That is really where my enjoyment stops, though. The gunplay is dated, even for 2010. It takes a ton of bullets to take down normal civilians wearing nothing but clothes. You can take cover, but you will still be hit, and when you look out to shoot, you will nearly die... every time. It took me many tries just to get used to the shooting mechanics, and I failed over and over on the 2nd level of the game, completely frustrated. I got better as the game went on, and it became easier, but not any more fun.

I've heard the multiplayer is really fun, but I can't bring myself to play any more of the game after the extremely lackluster single player campaign.

3/10

reviewText:
Yeah don't mind my play time as this game tend to shutdown as soon as its buffering the first level.

For those with the same problem the solution is easy, I know its easy to find but hey one more one less your know.

Ok this game gots its high and low, and the major low I can recall would be the short play time to finish it. It barely took me 6-7 hours to finish it walking around most of the time. But for say with all that the story is nice, if you dont minde a fancy ending, and kane and lynch are probably 2 of the best wingman out there, they are original and doesnt care for ♥♥♥♥.

My 2 cents, its not worth a full retail price, and its not worth the present full retail price, I would suggest to wait for at least a 75 % sales on it, wich happen often....

reviewText:
Personally I love Kane and Lynch 2: Dog days. The theme of the game gives you a feeling of raw brutal criminality. The characters is like taken out of a action movie, two hardcore old timers in shanghai to do an armsdeal with the chinese mafia. But  something goes horribly wrong and Kane and Lynch ends up being hunted through the streets of shanghai, and the run of their life begins to escape the chineese mafia.
The game graphics are ok, at times the extra graphics effects can be a little annoying. But you have options for that.
The gameplay can seem a little booring and at time a little monotonous for some, its a typical hallway run for cover type of shooter.
This game is for people that loves the criminal action hero type of theme game, and there is not a lot of those kinda games around.
For me the game is all about the theme, the characters and the city scenery. The gaming critics around the world slaughtered this game, and it was no hit when it was released. But I say it deserves a try!!!

reviewText: This game. Got it through the humble bundle and decided to try it with a friend. His game kept crashing with no error messages, in the end it turned out to be because he didn't have headphones plugged in. When we finally got the game to 'work' it was a laggy, jumpy monstrosity. The jittery camera and the poor controls in combination with screentearing and slowdown made this unplayable. Multiple freezes of around 20 seconds each on my part (host) and finally a fatal crash that locked my computer and wouldn't even let me force quit or shut off my computer. Never again.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
One of THE worst games I have ever played in my life. What even is this?

This game is comprised of well, nothing. It's a 3 hour long game that's just a cover based shooter that is it. You go from room to room hiding behind anything you can in order to stay safe. You don't even need to come out of your cover because you can just fire around corners or over it with perfect accuracy.

There's also numerous problems with this game, there's around 10 weapons which range from useless or overpowered. However you do literally need to be on top of your enemy to actually land a hit as IO Interactive decided that all guns are accurate to about the length of a 15cm ruler. Any gore is actually censored for no apparent reason and the run mechanic pretty much gives you nausia after 5 seconds. They tried an attempt at a 'real life' run mechanic whereby the screen shakes all over the place like a 10 on the ricther scale is going down, adding super DOF with large amounts of light effects and motion blur. Another brain fart mechanic was the jumping over obstacles nonsense where you have to crouch and take cover behind the obstacle you want to climb then wait for the jump prompt to appear. Really? Add all those together and you have a cocktail that's so lethal, absinthe might as well be Robinsons.

Game assets are constantly reused, one car park level everyone had the same BMW in the same colour. It made me wonder if they thought nobody would notice or that their This game is not racist" statement when you load the game was trying to spell that China is indeed a knock off nation. Maybe that's why all of the guns were so innacurate too?

It seems that this game was born from two terrible franchises
date: Gears of War and the Dynasty Warriors franchise. Combine a tacky third person cover based shooter with hoards of SWAT that have no idea what they are doing from room to room and you create the love child that is Kane & Lynch 2. I'm not even going to mention one of the worst ending scenes in history so you can just play this monstrousity for yourself and live with the pain that I suffered.\n\n3/10

Cover doesn't do jack sh*t, you'll get shot anyways, and that's pretty bad in a game which combat mechanic consists solely of covering behind things and shoot.

And of course, what everybody hates, the graphics. This is like, the only game in history that eats memory to make the graphics ♥♥♥♥♥ier. It's supposed to look like it's a youtube video recorded with a cell phone camera. And it looks like it, but that only makes it all blurry and seizure inducing.

I got this game during the special sales for less than 7 € and I regret it. I don't think anyone should spend more than 1 € for this thing.

reviewText:
The game has a clearly distinct visual asthetic the developers were trying to convey. Unfortunately that aesthetic was a faux low bitrate/live footage/youtube camera simulation that didn't age well with the game; it makes the game feel like there is texture pop-in or there are glitches in the game rather than being perceived as an art style.

The campaign didn't make a lot of sense either. The entire story played out like a DLC add-on that was difficult to follow. The characters are in a strange land, get in trouble, shoot their way out of trouble, then the game ends abruptly. The gameplay mechanics are OK, but the aiming is terrible. You have to get really close to enemies to land a shot. Otherwise the reticle on any weapon is too big. The weapons aren't very diverse either.

The whole game can be completed in ~4hours.

4/10. If you were a big fan of the first game, then you'll probably want to play this. Otherwise there are much more polished 3rd-person shooters out there that don't try to overplay their hand in pushing an edgy" visual aesthetic."

reviewText:
Kayne and Lynch 2 DEFEATED!!!

What a mix of bad meets good.

Pros:

Smooth as butter gameplay on PC.
Environments look great and combat takes place in plenty of locations.
Lot's of powerful weaponry to use topped with great sound effects.
Lot's of shooting for the shoot 'em up junkie.
Partner AI Kane is actually useful and kills lot's of enemies.
Don't ♥♥♥♥ with whitey.

Cons:

Short. But I paid 5$ for it so I'm not complaining.
In one particular stage, your ability to aim is hindered by horrible cover camera angles and the crosshair being useless. How did this get pass testing?
While combat is fun, the pacing is hindered by to many enemies at certain points, bringing a sense of boredom from repetition.
The drunk camera while sprinting is wtf.

I say it's worth the 5$ on Steam if you skipped this game. Go check it out. Outside of one particular level, the game isn't bad. It just isn't anything special.

reviewText:
I bought this game last year in a sale without actually playing the first one, completed it in co-op with a friend in around 3 hours which is very short but worth it for the price which I have paid. I believe that many people were dissapointed with this game's lenght when they paid the full price.
The shooting mechanics are solid and fun, the action is great, the soundtrack is great too and atmospheric.
The game has a very unique art style, the whole game looks like a gritty amateur homemade movie shot by an unseen cameraman running after the player, complete with lens flares, distortions, blurs and even a shaky cam while sprinting which can be turned off. It's so bad it's good.
The game has a serious and mature storyline which gets kind of repetitive.
It basically goes like this:
Kane
recommended:
I need your help."
A few moments and dead bodies later...
"Let's get out of here!"
The environments are detailed and look authentic.
If I were to review this on release it would be terrible due to it's lenght but for what I bought it I really can't complain
The game takes you throught 3 hours of of non-stop action which follows the same routine: cover

reviewText: This game holds it's prime with it's amazing atmosphere. The soundtrack really made you feel part of the situation and feel worried. Not to mention the soundtrack gave it a very dark feel too which I enjoyed very much. The story felt a little too predictable and has it's share of bugs and glitches. One of the major bugs I bumped into was in the last mission. When I had aimed down the sights of my gun, the whole screen went pink. It took me about 30 minutes of messing around with settings until I ended up restarting the game and it had seemed to work fine. I think it was the restart or the fact I was able to hit the next checkpoint. Towards the end of the game it'll get pretty challenging which I feel was pretty nice and bad. Enemys had more and more health and dealt more and more damage further in the game. On normal I felt like the last 3 missions were expert difficulty. So expect to die a few if not a lot, even on normal. So overall this game holds key it's atmosphere and it's ability to bring you in the game and really be embraced into the situation which I thought was really amazing. At the end of the day this game is a 8/10

reviewText:
This is a very short game, but that doesn't necessarily make it bad. Although you can finish the singleplayer in a day, the characters and action make it something everyone should try. I've never seen a game with such a unique set of characters that make you love them and hate them at the same time. The faux video camera style of the game is really something to be seen.

The multiplayer is also fun for a couple of rounds, but it really isn't anything to keep you playing for days.

Is it worth $20? No.
Is it worth $5? Yes.

reviewText:
Before i write my rating so will i say this is MY personal preference of this game, thank you.

Story: 3/10 (didn't understand much of the story exept that i needed to kill people to escape)

Gameplay: 6/10 (Awkward cover system)

Visual: 6.5/10 (can't really say more before of my crappy PC)

Voice acting: 7/10 (heard better)

Sound reality: 8/10 (as before, heard better)

AI: 7.5/10 (got supriced the AI actually tried to flank me then in other games, which they just stand behind cover and pop up sometimes)

Overall rating from me: 6/10

And now to what i think about the game which is not a whole lot because of the numb get in the cover and shoot when the enemy pop up once in a while, and resurecting your partner. I will admit that this game is not a walk in the park as some may believe as you can easily die in this game if you're just trying to go gun blazin', which is not a good advice to do. The character per say can use a bit more character than just the crazy guy and the semi-stupid guy which just follows around for the ride. This game give the player different locations throughout Hong Kong. I dont have much more time to follow up with more of my thoughts on this but i sincerely say and hope that you dont buy this game as i did, even if you just want to shoot people for no reason in China, just buy CoD (Call of Duty) or CS (Counter Strike) instead. Well thanks for checking my rating/review of this game and i hope it will decide if its worth your purchase. Good bye and have a good time. -ZKD

reviewText:
So after beating the first Kane & Lynch I can fairly say that they improved a lot of things that really bugged me. Shooting is more accurate (still a little fustrating at times especially when the bullets are not going where you aim), they added hit markers to indicate that you hit them and where. The levels are drastically better designed in this one, from the streets of Shanghai to the dirty cluttered sweat shops, everything is beautifully done giving you a sense of realism the last one lacked. The variety of weapons was definitely welcomed, there were several different kinds of pistols, machine guns, and shotguns. This game encourages you to experiment with each one to find out which compliments your playing style. They improved the cover system as well by simply giving a cover button, letting you control where and how you want to take cover, its way better but could use some tightening up.

The characters Kane & Lynch are better represented and displayed this time around, Kane is again hastily trying to rush to his own agenda (doesn't really contribute to the story beyond the point of telling us what happened to his daughter who we saved last game, and providing some assistence in fire fights), Lynch on the other hand puts on a pretty good show, I actually felt bad for the guy, he had his life together then all these bad events start to happen. There are plenty of memorable moments in this game, like when Kane & Lynch get sliced up all around thier bodies and they have to escape while running around completely naked. A lot of tense fire fights and action to keep you busy (which was one good thing about the first game), it rarely slows down to catch your breath, you always want to keep going and see what craziness is going to happen next.

For the most part this game was really good with only a couple of issues that bothered me, one was the camera, they were going for an amatuer filmed experience, its a great idea but in practice it got really annoying and bothersome, so I'm glad the developers thought of putting an option to disable it (steady cam). Its very shaky at tmes which can throw you off because the game has a lot of tense battles, you don't want the camera to assist the enemy, so I ended up turning steady cam on. Another thing thing that bothered me was again the lack of any real story, this game is a short experience (beating it took me 4.6 hours) and there is no reason to replay it unless you want the achievements for beating it on hard or extreme. So I'm confused to why they didn't try to throw some more story, whether learning more about the character's past or adding some information about the current relationships these characters have. There is really nothing here story wise which is a shame because I like this game.

Kane & Lynch 2 is a good game that I recommend giving it a shot, but since the multliplayer is dead the $10 price is pretty good, not worth $60. Playing co-op with a friend is also a great idea for a short acton packed experience.

reviewText: One of the most underrated games ever made. Beneath the cookie-cutter gameplay lies disturbing and damning revelations about modern FPS games. The hand-held camera visual style adds a visceral touch to the goings on, but it's the up-close headshots being pixellated out that should do the most psychological damage to the thinking gamer. This game will make you really think about the violence being carried out on-screen.\n\nThe two anti-heroes are also well worth the entry fee and their depressingly familiar descent into violence really makes you question where there's any good guys here. There is a very abrupt ending (almost akin to how the Pink Panther series ended back in the day) so a sequel is unsure... but definitely play through both games just so you can say I was there

reviewText:
So after beating the first Kane & Lynch I can fairly say that they improved a lot of things that really bugged me. Shooting is more accurate (still a little fustrating at times especially when the bullets are not going where you aim), they added hit markers to indicate that you hit them and where. The levels are drastically better designed in this one, from the streets of Shanghai to the dirty cluttered sweat shops, everything is beautifully done giving you a sense of realism the last one lacked. The variety of weapons was definitely welcomed, there were several different kinds of pistols, machine guns, and shotguns. This game encourages you to experiment with each one to find out which compliments your playing style. They improved the cover system as well by simply giving a cover button, letting you control where and how you want to take cover, its way better but could use some tightening up.

The characters Kane & Lynch are better represented and displayed this time around, Kane is again hastily trying to rush to his own agenda (doesn't really contribute to the story beyond the point of telling us what happened to his daughter who we saved last game, and providing some assistence in fire fights), Lynch on the other hand puts on a pretty good show, I actually felt bad for the guy, he had his life together then all these bad events start to happen. There are plenty of memorable moments in this game, like when Kane & Lynch get sliced up all around thier bodies and they have to escape while running around completely naked. A lot of tense fire fights and action to keep you busy (which was one good thing about the first game), it rarely slows down to catch your breath, you always want to keep going and see what craziness is going to happen next.

For the most part this game was really good with only a couple of issues that bothered me, one was the camera, they were going for an amatuer filmed experience, its a great idea but in practice it got really annoying and bothersome, so I'm glad the developers thought of putting an option to disable it (steady cam). Its very shaky at tmes which can throw you off because the game has a lot of tense battles, you don't want the camera to assist the enemy, so I ended up turning steady cam on. Another thing thing that bothered me was again the lack of any real story, this game is a short experience (beating it took me 4.6 hours) and there is no reason to replay it unless you want the achievements for beating it on hard or extreme. So I'm confused to why they didn't try to throw some more story, whether learning more about the character's past or adding some information about the current relationships these characters have. There is really nothing here story wise which is a shame because I like this game.

Kane & Lynch 2 is a good game that I recommend giving it a shot, but since the multliplayer is dead the $10 price is pretty good, not worth $60. Playing co-op with a friend is also a great idea for a short acton packed experience.

reviewText:
I have extremely mixed feelings about this game. Many people hate it, and i agree for the base price this game is not worth the experience. But as an experiement, and analysed as an artistic opportunity, all i can say it is that its an opportunity unfortunately wasted.
The art style of home-made, gritty hand-held camera footage works whonders for atmosphere and unique style, but the game itself is extremely unoriginal, uninspired, and all in all BORING.

That being said, if you are one to look past gameplay elements and bugs in order to enjoy a good story, you will be left wanting more. But not in a good way, more in the sense that they did not flesh out the story enough, and elements just DID NOT make sense. Its constant threat of death and danger just desensitizes the player after a short while, but granted, it DOES pace the action very well, with the intensity of firefights increasing as the story progresses. But in the end, its a potentially great game that ends up being wasted.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: A game that tries very hard with gritty realism like an exhilarating documentary experience. I don't see why the game gets crucified by most reviews. Sure the story sucks, but the visuals and sound are incredible. I'm an artist that appreciates a unique visual/sound experience of complex ambient sound-scape layers generated from real city noises, vintage synthesizers, guitar amplifiers creating a vastly real world experience in the perspectives of a two drugged up inebriated criminals.  Two bad asses fleeing China after a botched arms deal in the international black market.  The gameplay feels more like an arcade shooter with an interesting set of complex disastrous situations to blast your way out of.  Replay value is found in the elaborate online co-op missions and reattempting the main story on the highest difficulty for maximum experience.  It's one of those games you love for sheer badassery of the experience over all other matters. And be warned, some things in gang wars do get ruthlessly extreme but I won't spoil any of it until some of you are shocked by these parts of the game yourself.

reviewText: For as long as it lasts, Kane & Lynch 2: Dog Days is a good game. reviewText:
A flawed, divisive shooter that focuses on a story of nihilism and brutal violence.

Its unique design choices far overwhelm the flaws though.
Right from the start, the first thing that hits you is its art style, which is a fully realized gritty, and grimy Shanghai.

The game never lets up from its dark tone, and this will divide players from loving or hating this game. If you dont mind a game with a darker tone, with a focus on antiheroes who dont actually become heroes, this game may surprise you.

From its intentionally inaccurate weapons that force you to spray, to its visual effects and sound design, it sucks you into the underground world of violence, and 2 Anti heroes.

Word of caution, At 5 Bucks, this is a steal, but multiplayer is pretty empty now, and so is Coop.

There is a stand alone Arcade mode but that wont last very long.

Still, this is well worth getting for the Campaign Alone at a discount.

reviewText: OK, this game is not good, I mean not good at all, at least that's what all the reviews say. And they are RIGHT, at least from one point of view. reviewText: This game holds it's prime with it's amazing atmosphere. The soundtrack really made you feel part of the situation and feel worried. Not to mention the soundtrack gave it a very dark feel too which I enjoyed very much. The story felt a little too predictable and has it's share of bugs and glitches. One of the major bugs I bumped into was in the last mission. When I had aimed down the sights of my gun, the whole screen went pink. It took me about 30 minutes of messing around with settings until I ended up restarting the game and it had seemed to work fine. I think it was the restart or the fact I was able to hit the next checkpoint. Towards the end of the game it'll get pretty challenging which I feel was pretty nice and bad. Enemys had more and more health and dealt more and more damage further in the game. On normal I felt like the last 3 missions were expert difficulty. So expect to die a few if not a lot, even on normal. So overall this game holds key it's atmosphere and it's ability to bring you in the game and really be embraced into the situation which I thought was really amazing. At the end of the day this game is a 8/10

reviewText:
i) This sequel has way better gameplay than the first Kane & Lynch.
ii) Its graphics somehow, often  reminded me of the image of a typical 80's movie on a VHS cassette, they are very good in their own way.
iii) Good use of interactive scenes.
iv) At last, no Windows Live. Steam achievements. Hooray.

a) A big con is the duration of the game. It's really short.
b) I shouldnt forget to mention that multiplayer is dead.
c) There aren't many characters like in the first game. Also the personalities of Kane & Lynch, aren't so emphasized like the first one.
d) The plot is a bit weak and although they tried to create a connection between the first and the second game, it failed but anyway it doesn't matter that much.

I'd love to watch a movie based on the characters or the game itself, but with more details and no plot-holes.

Recommended, wait till you find it on sale for like 4 - 5 euros.

reviewText:
If you're expecting a solid and interesting thirdpersonshooter, look elsewhere, the gameplay -while functional- is the standard modern shooter fare:
cover based shooting
bloodyscreensoreal
annoying squadmate that gets in the line of fire
press X to stealthkill
carry only two weapons at maximum
blind fire and hipfire near useless
wait for your squadmate to open the door for you
help your squadmate over the fence
shoot explosive barrels
etc. etc. etc.

The game doesn't even try to hide that it is uninspired, it has no gimmicks at all, the mechanics never evolve, it's just a shooting gallery from start to finish.
So if you're coming in from a gaming perspective, stay away. Because this game is nauseatingly generic and wants to be a movie really bad, it has that nasty framework that people are so fed up with these days, i.e: corridor-shooting gallery-cutscene-repeat"

But here's where things might get a bit controversial: if you come in from the perspective of a movie fanatic
date: and review the game as if it were a movie
recommended: this game is actually pretty neat! It turns out that it works pretty well as a pseudo-movie.\nand since i didn't go in expecting a good game
hoursPlayed: and just wanted to see how the game handled that striking neo-noir theme its got going on. it actually didn't disappoint in that department.\n\nThe cinematography and level compositions are gorgeous. Gritty city decay contrasted against neon-spangled streets

It's field recordings of city noise interwoven with eerie electronic patterns and feverish soundscapes of pulsating drone.\nI personally think that it all is meant to convey the mind of lynch

reviewText:
PLEASE make Kane and lynch 3! This one’s SO good.
This is one the most atmospheric shooters ever made.  I don’t understand the bad reviews for this game because it is addictive and stylish and creates a feeling of tension and dread and exhilaration like no other shooter I’ve played, and I’ve played a lot of shooters.  The aiming is difficult but that’s what makes the game so unique because your shots will go astray meaning you really need to judge each weapons handling, recoil,  bullet trajectory and move to a position where the weapon can be best utilised. That’s what’s so great about this game is that it forces you to keep moving and create better angles and tactical positions with each fire fight you can figure out your own strategy. I played on the higher difficulties and it is very challenging and satisfying to think up a plan and execute it or try something else when it doesn’t work.
The game is short and repetitive but that’s the only negative. It has great characters, environments, graphics, phenomenal weapon sounds, tight game play, and rewards risk taking, strategy, and creative movement in a fire fight.
It’s a shame they won’t make a third because I would love to see another game like this with more weapons, items, maybe opportunities for stealth. But really, Kane and lynch 2 is already so refined you wouldn’t have to change much. I love the handheld shaky cam style of the game and the lens flare and just the general grittiness. I-O interactive needs to make the third one. Seriously.

reviewText:
I can't really recommend this game.

I really tried to like it and push on in the campaign, but there is just some things that bug the **** out of me.

- Story isn't good, but are not bad either. In the beginning it's confusing though.
- The camera tends to bug and makes the game unplayable from time to time. (By not follow you in cover and by doing that, you are not able to take proper shots without having to stand up and expose yourself)
- Cover system is not that good, i got killed several times without looking, no matter where the enemies stand. Oh yeah, 50% of all the times i looked i get shot isntantly with no time to shoot anybody.
- SMG's.... they suck for you... but apparently the AI can headshot you from 100 kilometers distance without a sweat.
- Shotguns should be a close quarters weapon.. can almost be used as sniper rifle.
- It might be a 2010 game, but i've seen better graphics in games from before that time.
- Somewhat boring characters.
-There's no ending.. just a short cutscene with little to no content.

Must say that the atmoshpere as a whole is quite dark, that's one thing i like about it. No heroic stuff like in so many games, and whole story isn't great, it's not bad either. Basicly it's just about 2 dudes who got themselves into some ♥♥♥♥, but that's it.

So buttom line is: Gameplay is choppy and buggy. Story is average.. AI is a bit stupid and predictable, but can also prove very challenging by headshotting you through cover. So, nope, won't recommend it. It's bad. And before you judge my review, yes i did complete the story mode. Replay value is zero.

reviewText:
Kane and Lych

A pair almost as misunderstood as the games they inhabit.
Both the original and the sequel do not conform to the norm.
They have their flaws - but despite or perhaps even because of these flaws they are valuable. They are different.

This game presents a unique and well executed visual style. The weapons feel potent and sound brutal. After finishing this game I felt compelled to visit China and Shanghai. To soak up the grime, sweat and the thick, heavy air. To see the decaying buildings and the crime and the corruption.

Whether these things exist in this way? I dont know, but for me this game recreates precisely what it feels to be in a place I have never visited and for me that is the essence of what a game should do.

To provide some context, games like Mirrors Edge, Far Cry 1 and Far Cry 2 also had this effect on me.

If you want to sit in your living room and glide through bland environments in your gucci camo yelling oorah, then leave and never return.

If you want to stumble through the streets of Shangai naked in the rain, in a nightmare that doesnt end until it does :), then play this game,

As with every game, best played in CO-Op.

reviewText:
This one is controversial, but I recommend it since it provides a unique experience... and goes very cheap on sales.

Yes, the game is very short (3-4h) - but it goes very well with the intensity of the gameplay and the unique camera work.

The game is presented as if it was shot from a hand - the screen wobbles all the time, there are tears, artifacts... and pixelization of victims/nudity/mutilation. It can be nauseating (I had to make a break and finish the game on second evening), but it also provides a oddly realistic feel. Paired with some disturbing scenes it can be a strong experience.

Gameplay is very hectic. We often have to push forward to avoid being overwhelmed - the covers are not impenetrable and we'll often get flanked. The enemies are rather dumb, but there's not much time to wonder about that.

I had a great chance to play the game in co-op with a friend who already finished it once and it clicked with the game's plot - he was playing Lynch who lived in Hong Kong for some time, while I played Kane who was fresh from the airport :)

Short, but very intense.

reviewText: Despite its atrocious length (just under 4hrs on medium) and oft-annoying cover system, I really enjoyed this game. That said, I am fully aware that Im one of the very few who think this way:). I do have my reasons, however. Firstly, the game possesses an atmosphere that very few developers can match, even to this date. Its gritty, unforgiving, brutal and very realistic/life-like. Even before I got to the ending, which basically confirmed my thoughts, I constantly felt like in a 1990s Michael Mann movie (Heat, anyone?). The shaky cam-style, along with its visual effects is another major plus in my book. Immersion is simply a given, the mechanic is not violated or overused. Voice acting is a third plus, but only if you consider the two main antagonists (cant really name them protagonists, now can we). So basically, I got so immersed in the world and the perdicament that the two psychos got involved in, that I forgave the game its length, its problematic game mechanics, heck, even the (at times) mediocre graphics. I did not really dwell on the fact that the characters are visualised in a less-detailed manner, the Shanghai setting sold me alone. I will not grade the multiplayer, as by now, it is totally dead, arcade mode is fun, but given the low number of maps, its a try-a-few-rounds kind of entertainment. To sum up, if you are into gritty, brutal crime stories told from a view point of two very despicable personas, Id say go for it:) I sure had fun with them.

reviewText:
K&L2 is a cover shooter with a very good single-player/two player story mode and novel themed multiplayer modes. Its story mode is very tightly written and well-voiced, and it took me through gunfight to gunfight at a very quick pace. MP is more straightforward, but is more involved than other shooters' MP modes. All are co-op/team based to an extent, but they all boil down to earning the highest score at the other criminals' (your teammates) expense.

The shooting feels appropriate, the cover shooting system is quite good (for a cover shooter) and moves at a very frantic pace. It's almost always easier to survive by moving over cover to get closer or to flank. The guns are interesting if not punchy, firing blindly from behind cover is possible, and fire extinguishers and gas cans provide meaty explosions when thrown and shot. Solid, if not innovat

K&L2 is exceedingly stylish, and it received too much undeserved negativity for its divisive art design. I love the hell out of it.

reviewText: Kane and Lynch 2: Dog Days is a much improved version of it's predecessor.  The ai has been improved, as has the cover system and hit detection.  What stands out the most about this title however, is the dramatic improvement in graphics.  The developers really have gone to great lengths to deliver a visual feast.  At times, the natural movement of the camera combined with the stylized but detailed graphics deliver an almost cinematic experience.  Like the original, Kane and Lynch 2 also featured an online co-op mode, Steam Overlay support, and of course widescreen resolutions.  The title is so improved over the original, I would endorse this title at full price.  Altogether the game is a solid choice at full price and a must buy on sale.

reviewText:
It looked like a good game when I was buying it, but after playing 2 hours of storyline, I do not recommend this game.

TL;DR: Characters (Kane & Lynch) - awesome, story - looks good, gameplay - sux; get Spec Ops: The Line instead.

Pros:
If you are looking for a game with good characters (i like kane & lynch) and maybe a story then try to get it. Maybe the gameplay will not ♥♥♥♥ you of so much as me.

Cons:
The shooting system in this game is weird. Recoil on every weapon is weird, enemy can shoot you through whole alley, but you miss every shot. Enemies after getting 5 hits to the head, fall down, 10 seconds contemplate if they shoud die, then stand up and run around like nothing happened. Your partner is idiot, leaving enemies to flank you from side and shoot you from behind, he takes the only valuable cover leaving you to run around in the open getting shot and if you manage to get good cover, he wil stand in your shot just when enemies are shooting at you. You are getting hit by enemies you cannot see from a weird angle even if you are in the cover. Character leaves cover when he wants to, causing a lot of situations when instead of moving he will leave cover and even if crouched before he will stand up.

I wil try to finish the game for achievs, but curretnly I am contemplating really uninstalling it from my library.

reviewText:
This game had the chance to be a completely average shooter. I would have played it and moderately enjoyed it like I did with the first Kane & Lynch. This game, however, is riddled with bugs.

The very first cut scene in the game wouldn't display and gave me a gray screen instead. This happened multiple times throughout the game and closing to the main menu and trying it again usually fixed it.

The reason I stopped playing is because all of a sudden the cover system stopped working. I would get behind a pillar and when I would try to lean out to shoot somebody, the crosshair would be centered on the back of my own head. I couldn't find a way to fix this so I just stopped playing.

When the game you make has a single mechanic, you should probably make sure that mechanic works.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
I think I got this game on sale in 2010 for about 5 bucks or so. Even at that price, I really can't recommend it.

When I first tried playing the game, I got DESTROYED by run of the mill enemies that could seemingly shoot through my cover and flank me with the greatest of ease. I got frustrated and shelved the game for 5 years. I'm not sure what bug crawled up my backside, but I decdied to install the game and grind away until  I saw the game through completion.

I really enjoy the atmosphere in this game, and I am probably one of the few who actually enjoy the 'shaky cam' aspect/angles they were going for. That is really where my enjoyment stops, though. The gunplay is dated, even for 2010. It takes a ton of bullets to take down normal civilians wearing nothing but clothes. You can take cover, but you will still be hit, and when you look out to shoot, you will nearly die... every time. It took me many tries just to get used to the shooting mechanics, and I failed over and over on the 2nd level of the game, completely frustrated. I got better as the game went on, and it became easier, but not any more fun.

I've heard the multiplayer is really fun, but I can't bring myself to play any more of the game after the extremely lackluster single player campaign.

3/10
